para.paratext: Since 1997, the Georgia Code has recognized a specific hearsay exception for medical records in civil cases. Former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-18 (current O.C.G.A. § 24-8-826) provided for the admissibility of medical reports in narrative form in their entirety (including diagnoses and opinions) when proper notification was sent to the opposing party. Also, the statute allowed the admission of written medical reports without requiring the production of the doctor as a sworn witness at trial, and, unlike “business records” admissible under former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-14, the medical reports admissible under this section could include diagnoses and opinions in addition to facts. Current O.C.G.A. § 24-8-826 is almost identical.

The written report must be in “narrative form,” which has been defined as a one “which set forth, in story form, the author's assessment of the patient's history, examination, diagnosis, treatment, prognosis, or interpretation of tests or examinations, including the basis therefor.”[1] “Thus, the law authorizes the admission of only those reports which, rather than consisting of unexplicated medical terms and uninterpreted scientific test results, set forth the relevant information in prose language that is more readily understandable to laymen. Other medical records which would require an expert analysis to demonstrate their import are still subject to a hearsay objection.”[2]

In Lott v. Ridley,[3] the Georgia Court of Appeals reviewed the admission of medical reports under the hearsay exception in light of the plaintiff's contention that two of the doctors made no attempt to use lay language or to explain any of the medical terms they used. At trial, plaintiff's counsel read the reports of a chiropractor and a neurologist into the record. The appellate court found that the chiropractor's report was properly admitted under the medical records exception as it presented the relevant aspects of plaintiff's diagnosis, treatment, and prognosis in a logical, narrative form and the preparer attempted to explain medical terms in the context of the report. However, the court found that the trial court abused its discretion in admitting a neurologist's report because it did not provide a narrative summarizing the plaintiff's condition and treatment and did not explain medical terms.[4] A healthcare professional's opinions and diagnosis are admissible through his certified report without his testimony.

Medical records may still be admissible as regular business entries under O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803 even when not admissible under the medical narratives exception, O.C.G.A. § 24-8-826. Both Fed. R. Evid. 803(6) and O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(6) provide for the admission of business records, including statements of medical diagnoses and opinions. With adoption of this rule, medical records and reports are now admissible under the business records exception when they would have been excluded previously under Georgia's former Business Records Act, former O.C.G.A. § 24-3-14.

Medical records have been problematic as regular business entries because they often contain material such as the personal history of the patient, a detailed description of the injury, and diagnostic statements which are not typical regular business entries. Ironically, in one case,[5] a 31-page patient file was admitted into evidence even though only parts of it were admissible. Nontestimonial hospital records stating that defendant presented as “intoxicated” were admissible in prosecution for DUI less safe under the business records exception to hearsay rule since the records were made to facilitate defendant's treatment and not in anticipation of prosecution.[6]

The Georgia Court of Appeals first extensive consideration of a medical history file was in Knudsen v. Duffee-Freeman, Inc.[7] where it held that medical history file and papers containing diagnostic opinions were inadmissible. The Georgia legislature responded to this construction of the hearsay exception by adopting a resolution which declared that it intended for the statute to be interpreted liberally to allow records made in ordinary course of business to be admissible in evidence without producing the party(ies) who made entries. Subsequently, in Martin v. Baldwin,[8] the Georgia Supreme Court held that this legislative resolution was void and held that hospital records which contain opinion evidence are not admissible under the business record exception to the hearsay rule.[9] However, O.C.G.A. § 24-8-803(6) now allows statements of “medical diagnoses and opinions.” The trial court has the discretion to reject business records whose trustworthiness has not been established.
